Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Early Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Remember to include your personal experience or observation.

Human aging is like a plant growing bigger. When we are babies, we are small and need help for everything. Then, we grow bigger and can do more things by ourselves. Our bodies change too, like when we lose our baby teeth and grow adult ones. Our skin gets wrinkles as we get older, just like a favorite toy that has been played with for a long time. Sometimes, we might not see or hear as well as before, but we gain wisdom and learn many things. I remember when I was little, I couldn't reach the cookies on the high shelf. Now, I can easily grab them because I've grown taller. Aging is a natural process that happens to everyone, making us unique and special in our own way.

Human aging is when people get older. As they grow up, their bodies change. They might not be as fast or strong as before. Their hair might turn gray or fall out. Sometimes, they might need glasses to see well. Also, they might not remember things as easily as when they were younger. This is all part of getting old. But even though their bodies change, people still keep learning and enjoying life. They just do it in different ways than when they were kids.

Human aging is like a long journey that everyone goes on. You start as a baby, then grow into a child, and finally become an adult. As you grow older, your body changes. Your hair might turn gray or fall out. Your skin may become wrinkled. You might need glasses to see things far away. You might also start to move more slowly and need more rest. These changes happen very slowly, over many years. It's a natural part of life, like how a seed grows into a tree. Even though it's a long journey, it's important to take care of ourselves every day, so we can enjoy each stage of life.

When we're babies, we're tiny and can't do much. We grow bigger and stronger each year. Our bodies change as we get older. This is called 'human aging'. It happens to everyone. Aging makes us wise and more able to do things. But it also means we get tired easier and need glasses to see well. Our skin wrinkles and our hair turns gray or white. Some people think aging is like getting older like a car does, but it's not. A car can break down and stop working, but people keep living even when they're very old.

Human aging is like a plant growing. Just like a plant, people start small and get bigger as they get older. As we grow, our bodies change. We get taller, and our bones get stronger. We learn new things and remember more. Our brains grow too, but not like our bodies. Instead of getting bigger, our brains get smarter. This is because we learn and experience more things as we age.

As we continue to grow, we start to slow down. Our bodies don't work as fast as they used to. We might not be able to run as fast or see as well. Our skin might get wrinkles, which are little lines that form when our skin gets old. These changes happen because our cells, which are like tiny building blocks in our body, start to wear out. They don't work as well as they used to, just like a toy that has been played with a lot.
